awd_titl_txt: Turbulent Ion Heating in the Magnetosheath
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's magnetic field encloses it in a protective cocoon, called the magnetosphere, deflecting most of the solar wind around it.  The solar wind is a stream of charged particles, approximately equal numbers of ions and electrons, and magnetic fields blowing outward from the Sun, which varies in intensity with solar activity.  The solar wind moves so fast that when it encounters the magnetosphere a shock forms upstream from it.  As solar wind plasma passes through the shock it is slowed down and then flows around the magnetosphere in a sheath region, called the magnetosheath.   In this region the magnetic field is erratic or turbulent and evidence suggests that magnetosheath ions are heated as this turbulence is dissipated.  The topic is compelling because the potential importance of turbulence and associated ion heating has only recently been recognized. Ions in the magnetosheath eventually cross the magnetopause to provide the dominant source of magnetospheric plasmas, thus changes in their temperature and other properties can have a profound effect on the stability of the magnetosphere itself, which can lead to explosive releases of energy during geomagnetic storms and substorms.  The methodology for this study is creative and an important advance over previous studies because it is the first self-consistent comprehensive treatment of this turbulence and its dissipation. As such, the potential for new discoveries is high. Advances in understanding will have benefit to society because, in the longer term, they will contribute to the development of an improved predictive capability that can be used to minimize the impacts of such events.  This research contributes to the development of a scientific workforce by training a postdoctoral student and a graduate student.  Research results will be disseminated through publications, conferences, and community outreach.

In order to fulfill its objectives, this study investigate how Alfvenic turbulence heats magnetosheath ions, how the heating process saturates, the rate at which energy is transferred to the ions, how electromagnetic energy is transported to support the heating process, how secondary wave emissions develop during the heating, and how the heating process influences the bulk characteristics of the magnetosheath plasma.  The primary tool is a 3D hybrid particle in cell model.  The proposal uses wave/ion heating events observed by the THEMIS satellites to both specify initial conditions and to validate simulation results.  An innovative aspect is the coupled treatment of both the cascade processes associated with plasma turbulence and the additional instabilities that arise from the anisotropies that develop in the ion distributions.

por.por_cntn:
The region of space Sunward of Earth, and just outside the volume dominated by the geomagnetic field, is a key region for defining the nature of matter populating near-Earth space. This region, known as the magnetosheath, is pervaded by broadband electromagnetic fluctuations in the frequency range from 0.01-10 Hz (when measured from the spacecraft) that appear to alter the properties of the plasmas piopulating this region of space. Characterizing these fluctuations and the manner in which they interact with the positively charged particles (ions) constituting these plasmas was the topic of this research. This characterization was pursued using a combination of observational and numerical techniques utilizing multi-point measurements from the Magnetospheric Multi-Scales mission (MMS) mission and supported by statistics from the THEMIS spacecraft with approaches tailored for the properties of the plasma observed.

     
It was found using a set of analysis techniques that compared the electromagnetic field and flow measurements between the 4 MMS spacecraft that these fluctuations could be described in terms of a specific kind of electromagnetic plasma wave known as an Alfven wave. These waves were found to have a range of wavelengths, or spatial scales, that included the scale-size of the orbits of the ions around the magnetic field through this region of space. These fluctuations in plasma physics are generally described as kinetic Alfven waves. It was demonstrated however, that these waves cannot be simply described as a series of traveling wave-fronts, but instead tend to be filamentary, or tubular, in form, aligned along the pervasive background magnetic field. It was also shown that these features drive counter-streaming flows of energy back and forth along the background magnetic field.


Simultaneous analyses of the ion particle distributions immersed in these fields were performed. This analysis showed a correlation between the energization of the whole distribution (heating) and enhanced wave energy when heightened degrees of filamentation in the fields was observed. It was also found that specific distortions of the normally smooth distribution of ions as a function of their velocity, was observed when encountering enhanced wave energy densities. 


To explore how the interaction between these waves and particles operates, numerical simulations were performed. These provided insights into the wave-particle interactions that are not accessible from spacecraft measurements alone. These took two forms. The first approach was based on a 3-dimensional empirical model for the observed fields derived directly from the observations in which the motions of a large number of ions were traced. This was performed to characterize the evolution of the ion distributions through interaction with the observed fields. The second approach used a self-consistent description of the interaction between the particles and the wave-fields with the intent of examining the ion distribution temporal evolution subject to constraints placed on this evolution due to secondary effects. Specifically, these secondary effects, known in plasma physics as instabilities, act to limit the form of possible ion distributions through wave emission.  

The first simulation approach revealed how the ion distributions observed could be formed by the action of the observed wavefields and how specific observed wave features were crucial in replicating the observations. Specifically, it was show how the ion distribution function was driven by scattering through the action of the fluctuating, filamentary, electric and magnetic fields via a stochastic, or random process, in which some ions gained energy, whilst other lost energy, but on average a net transfer of energy from the wavefields to the ion plasma occurred. It was shown how his process is highly sensitive to the filamentary form of the wavefields and requires counter propagating modes along the magnetic field to operate effectively. 


The second simulation approach showed how the form of the ion distribution is regulated by action of a specific form of instability known as the mirror instability which limits the non-uniformity (anisotropy)  of the ion distribution relative to the background magnetic field. For an imposed background of Alfvenic fluctuations it was shown how this interaction can lead to the generation of filamentary structures.

 
In summary, the intellectual merit of the research was in the creation of a self-consistent model for the conversion of energy contained in turbulent magnetosheath fields variations to particle kinetic energy via the the heating and energization of magnetosheath ions. This research has broad impact because the interactions characterized, modeled and simulated in this research will be active in other regions within the Heliosphere and beyond.  While the specific magnetic field geometries in different contexts lead to differences in the form of the ion velocity distributions observed, the scattering and energization processes documented in this research are general in nature. The insights gained through this research concerning these processes are therefore of general interest across different plasma domains.
